title: Relational Algebra
i
is not a full-blown
SQL
i

language, but rather a way to gain theoretical understanding of relational processing. As such it shouldn’t make references to physical entities such as tables, records and fields; it should make references to abstract constructs such as relations, tuples and attributes. Saying that, I won’t use the academic terms in this document and will stick to the more widely known layman terms - tables, records and fields.

inline_content.Text: language, but rather a way to gain theoretical understanding of relational processing. As such it shouldn’t make references to physical entities such as tables, records and fields; it should make references to abstract constructs such as relations, tuples and attributes. Saying that, I won’t use the academic terms in this document and will stick to the more widely known layman terms - tables, records and fields.

title: A couple of rules of relational algebra before we get started:

inline_content.Text: A couple of rules of relational algebra before we get started:

title: The operators used in relational algebra work on whole tables rather than individual records.

inline_content.Text: The operators used in relational algebra work on whole tables rather than individual records.

title: The first expression is evaluated and the resulting table is given the alias A. This table is then used within the second expression to give the final table with an alias of B.

inline_content.Text: The first expression is evaluated and the resulting table is given the alias A. This table is then used within the second expression to give the final table with an alias of B.

title: A natural join sticks two tables together using a common field shared between the tables.

inline_content.Text: A natural join sticks two tables together using a common field shared between the tables.

i
